NoteLiteral.En:
Entry requirements:
•	Student at any of the universities of the ECIU;
•	B2 level of English language proficiency.
Applicants need to attach a copy of ID card / passport (document issued by the country of origin) to enrol in the KTU virtual learning environment. This does not apply to KTU students (if you are a KTU student, you may attach a blank page).
Students, who are admitted and accepted the offered place in the micro-module, will be informed by email on the steps to take in order to gain access to the KTU virtual learning environment. Students will receive an email from the teacher of the micro-module on the first day of the start of module.
Students who have dropped out from the KTU micro-module(s) in the autumn 2024 are not eligible to enrol in the KTU micro-module(s) in the spring 2025.

Description.En:
Have you ever considered how the European Union's ambitious goal to become the world's first climate-neutral continent by the 2050s will impact industries and entire value chains? What new structures and strategies for circular value and supply chains will emerge? What governance modes, value chains, transformation scenarios, and new stakeholders will appear? And how intense their engagement needs to be to make the value of the supply chains circle?

The micromodule provides the latest theoretical and practical knowledge on how to successfully support the entire value or supply chain in becoming more circular and sustainable. This micromodule covers four major and interconnected topics: the transformation of global value chains challenged by sustainability pressure; the concept of circular value and supply chains as pivotal elements for industries to become more circular; the concept of stakeholder engagement as a cornerstone for integrating circular practices throughout the value chain; and the main enablers supporting the transformation of entire value or supply chains towards greater circularity and sustainability.

The module's content directly aligns with real-world scenarios. Europe aims for a competitive and climate-neutral economy. The imperative for value or supply chains to be circular and sustainable is undeniable and driven by the necessity to mitigate climate change, improve resource efficiency, reduce waste, comply with regulations, align with consumer preferences, and ensure long-term economic viability and resilience.

Title.En: Impact of global dynamism and external changes on value chains

NoteLiteral.En: By competing the micromodule, student will be able to understand the dynamism of global environment and its changes that effect value chains, their governance forms and transformation scenarios.

Title.En: Awareness of value (supply) chains transformations and relevant strategies

PrefLabel.En: adopt ways to reduce negative impact of consumption
promote the use of sustainable transport

NoteLiteral.En: By completing the micromodule, student will be able to comprehend how circular transformation redesigns value and supply chains and what are the main strategies and practices.

By completing the micromodule, student will be able to identify the main stakeholders in circular value and supply chains and understand their contributions to meeting sustainability goals through their actions.

Title.En: Identification and justification of enablers supporting circularity and sustainability

PrefLabel.En: minimise environmental impact on the surrounding area

NoteLiteral.En: By completing the micro-module, students will understand how standards, extended producer responsibility schemes, digital product passports, and green procurement support and contribute to sustainability and circularity throughout the entire value or supply chain.

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral:
The expected workload of the micromodule is around 14 hours per week. This includes time invested in watching the video lectures, reading the material, taking self-assessment questions, completing practical task, participating in the discussion forums and taking the exam.

The micromodule uses digital teaching methods and applications, including video lectures, case analysis, podcasts, practical task writing and exam. Self-assessment questions, guided examples, peer feedback, and a discussion forum support effectively acquire and correctly understand the materials and tasks provided.

To pass the micromodule, you must achieve a score of 50% or higher for each graded activity. The highest possible grade is 100%. When you complete all the required micromodule activities, you will earn a final grade.

The final grade of micromodule consists of practical task worth 50% and an exam also worth 50% of final grade. The practical task involves designing a circular value or supply chain in a selected industry or for a specific product or service. The exam comprises 10 questions covering all the material presented throughout the four weeks of the micro-module. Additionally, active participation in the discussion forum and completion of self-assessment questions after each video can earn up to 10% extra evaluation towards the final grade.

[Syllabus of the micro-module](https://uais.cr.ktu.lt/ktuis/stp_report_ects.mdl_ml?p_kodas=MM00M109&p_year=2024&p_lang=EN&p_stp_id=)

The micro-module will be delivered in the KTU virtual learning environment. When a student is enrolled in KTU, s/he will be informed by email on how to gain access to the micro-module.  
After the successful completion of the micro-module:
- In two weeks, a student will receive an email with the link to download the ECIU University micro-credential.
- In mid-June 2025, a student from other university than KTU will receive an email with the KTU Transcript of Records that might be presented for recognition of learning outcomes at the home university.
Is designed for everyone, who wants to take on the challenge of transforming the entire value or supply chain to become more circular and sustainable

The micromodule offers a unique perspective for gaining the latest theoretical and practical knowledge out the transformation of value and supply chains to be more circular and sustainable. It explores the challenges and opportunities in this transition, highlighting the main enablers that support greater circularity and sustainability in the entire value chain. The content represents an advanced scientific approach, complemented with real-world examples from companies and industries, fostering a comprehensive discussion of practices across various industry value chains.

This micromodule is part of Circular Economy Strategic Solutions, which also includes Circular Economy for Sustainability and Circular Business Models.

Entry requirements:

- Student at any of the universities of the ECIU;
- B2 level of English language proficiency.

Applicants need to attach a copy of ID card / passport (document issued by the country of origin) to enrol in the KTU virtual learning environment. This does not apply to KTU students (if you are a KTU student, you may attach a blank page).  

Students, who are admitted and accepted the offered place in the micro-module, will be informed by email on the steps to take in order to gain access to the KTU virtual learning environment. Students will receive an email from the teacher of the micro-module on the first day of the start of module.  

Students who have dropped out from the KTU micro-module(s) in the autumn 2024 are not eligible to enrol in the KTU micro-module(s) in the spring 2025.
